title-group.article-title: Acute Isolated Rupture of the Spring Ligament
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report and Review of the Literature

article-meta.aff: 2Foot and ankle surgeon, Buenos Aires, Argentina
3Foot and ankle fellow, Buenos Aires, Argentina

author-notes.corresp: Héctor José Masaragian, MD, Foot and Ankle Surgeon, EPTP, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Av Cerviño 4679, Piso 2, CP: 1425, Ciudad de Buenos Aires, Argentina Email: masa@cirugiadelpie.net

body.p: Level of Evidence: Level V, expert opinion.

Acute isolated injuries of the spring ligament with normal tibialis posterior tendon have been infrequently diagnosed. The incidence of this lesion is uncertain. The spring ligament is a main stabilizer of the medial longitudinal arch,4,17 and the inferior calcaneonavicular ligament is the most important aspect of the spring ligament for stability of the talonavicular joint.8 The differential diagnosis includes more common injuries, such as medial ankle fractures, midtarsal joint fractures or dislocation, tears of the tibialis posterior tendon, injuries of the deltoid ligament, or plantar fascia tears.

We found only 2 reported cases of an acute rupture of the spring ligament. The first involved a 19-year-old jumper, reported by Borton and Saxby2 in 1997, with an acute tear of the spring ligament that resembled a tibialis posterior tendon rupture, similar to our patient. The second, reported by Kann and Myerson,11 involved a 51-year-old man, whose injury occurred while hiking; the authors stated that the ligament rupture may have been associated with a normal tibialis posterior tendon.
In this article, we present an additional case and describe its operative management, with literature review.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 60-year-old tennis player felt sudden pain in the longitudinal arch while playing. He immediately noticed swelling and tenderness in that area extending upward toward the tibialis posterior to the retromalleolar region. He was seen in the emergency room and diagnosed with a medial ankle sprain. The initial treatment was rest, ice, and pain medication. After a few days, he came to our office for evaluation. He had no history of tendinopathy. He was weightbearing with pain, swelling, and tenderness below the navicular and along the tibialis posterior tendon.

Clinically, he had tibialis posterior tendon insufficiency with mild heel valgus and was not able to invert his foot (Figure 1). We believe that his inability to invert the foot was caused by pain, as the tibialis posterior tendon was uninjured. Radiographic findings were normal, and MRI results were positive, with fluid in the tendon sheath and an intrasubstance abnormality near the insertion of the spring ligament on the navicular (Figure 2). We suggested operative treatment.

A curvilinear incision was made behind the medial malleolus to the navicular tuberosity. The tibialis posterior tendon sheath was identified and opened, revealing a small amount of fluid. The tendon looked healthy, with no evidence of longitudinal or undersurface tears. There was no proximal pathology. Distally, we found a complete tear of the superomedial component of the spring ligament (Figure 3), which we repaired using a Vicryl No. 1 suture, advancing and reinserting the ligament to the navicular bone through 1.5-mm drill holes while holding the foot in an inverted position. After the repair, the foot position at rest was in plantarflexion and inversion with good restitution of the longitudinal arch (Figure 4). We used a short leg cast for 6 weeks in invertion, then a walker boot for another 4 weeks with progressive weightbearing. After that, a progressive rehabilitation program was established, and after a few weeks, the patient was able to resume his normal activities. Sports practice was allowed after 3 months.

caption.p: After the repair, note longitudinal arch appearance.

sec.p: After 8 years of follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic with normal function of his foot (Figure 5). He has normal shape of the hindfoot, and heel rise strength was symmetric. On postoperative radiographs, a slight talus drop and forefoot abduction were noted (Figure 6).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Anatomically, the calcaneonavicular, or spring, ligament consists of 2 bundles: 1 superomedial and 1 inferior. Besides both components, a third (inconstant) structure has been identified and called the oblique midplantar ligament.16

The superomedial bundle, which is inseparable from the inferior calcaneonavicular ligament, starts at the superomedial edge of the sustentaculum tali and the anterior edge of the anterior facet of calcaneus, sharing its insertion with fibers of the superficial deltoid ligament. It runs in a fan shape toward the edge of the superomedial and inferior navicular facet with an articular portion that support the talar head.15
The superomedial bundle is the portion of the calcaneus-navicular ligament that can be observed more easily during surgery, and it is the most frequently injured.9

The inferoplantar portion comes from the coronoid cavity of the calcaneus, in the anterior facet of the sustentaculum tali on the lower surface of the navicular, lateral to superomedial bundle.8 The oblique midplantar bundle runs between the anterior and medial facet of the calcaneus toward the tuberosity of navicular and is sometimes absent, being the thinnest of the 3 components.1

Histologic and biomechanical findings have determined that the inferoplantar portion has a collagen structure with no elastic properties, which the superomedial portion has; however, this last portion has fibrocartilage, which is the strongest and widest of the 3 structures.3,5,7
Avascularity of the central part of the superomedial portion of the spring ligament could be a predisposing factor for these ligament injuries, acute or chronic.12

The diagnosis is based on clinical findings. We found tenderness between the sustentaculum tali and the navicular, more plantar than medial, mild pes planus, heel valgus, and tibialis posterior tendon insufficiency.13 The history of trauma is relevant in these cases of acute tears of the spring ligament. MRI and ultrasonography can be helpful.14

There is no classification of isolated spring ligament injuries; Gazdag and Cracchiolo6 described one for spring ligament pathology associated with tibialis posterior tendon dysfunction with 3 types of injury:

list-item.p: Grade 1: either longitudinal tear within the midsubstance or partial tears at the ligament’s insertion on the sustentaculum tali or the navicular. The ligament does not appear lax. There appears to be either a single longitudinal tear or several small tears at the ligament insertion.
Grade 2: an obviously loose ligament that appears stretched, with or without visible tears in the midsubstance or the insertion site.
Grade 3: complete rupture of the ligament.

sec.p: Treatment of these types of lesions varies from ligament suture, advance or imbrication, to augmentation with the distal stump of tibialis posterior, with or without flexor digitorum longus tendon transfer. In severe cases, with no ligament to repair, a modified Cobb procedure (half tibialis anterior transfer through navicular) or a peroneus longus tendon transfer has been described.11

As the spring ligament rupture has been found in both young and adult patients, it should be included in the differential diagnosis with medial ankle fractures, midtarsal joint fractures or dislocation, and tears of the tibialis posterior tendon, deltoid ligament, or plantar fascia tears.

In 1997 Borton and Saxby2 reported an acute tear of the spring ligament that resembled a tibialis posterior tendon rupture. The patient was evaluated and diagnosed with a medial ankle sprain for months. In our case, the patient was misdiagnosed in the emergency room and treated as a medial ankle sprain. Borton and Saxby reported that after 6 months, they found a pes planovalgus deformity of the left foot with a positive “too many toes” sign. Single heel raise was achieved only with difficulty, and repetitive heel rise was impossible. A diagnosis of rupture of the spring ligament was made by exclusion, as with our patient. Borton and Saxby reattached the spring ligament along with a flexor digitorum longus tendon transfer through the navicular bone with an excellent result.

Kann and Myerson11 reported on a 51-year-old man who sustained the lesion while hiking. The authors found that the ligament rupture can be associated with a normal tendon. They performed a ligament suture and an augmentation with a tendon transfer.

According to Macklin et al,12 macroscopic evidence and histologic studies show a poor or avascular zone in the central area of the superomedial portion of the spring ligament, which may be the cause of injuries in that part. We suggest the repair of the ligament in the peripheral area or resection of the central part of the injured ligament with reattachment to the navicular, with or without extra procedures, according to the individual patient.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Acute isolated injuries of the spring ligament with normal tibialis posterior tendon are infrequently diagnosed. In our patient, the symptoms were those of a tibialis posterior tendon rupture. Because of the importance of diagnosing a spring ligament injury, we believe that it should be included in the differential diagnosis of medial foot and ankle trauma. MRI can be helpful in association with the clinical findings. We believe that operative treatment is indicated, with direct repair (if possible) in the vascular zone, with or without extra procedures.
